Most people miss the sunny days of summer but for me, I miss those summer rains 🌧️ 
 
Have you ever noticed how healthy a garden looks after a good rain? Watering a garden keeps plants alive, but rainwater makes them thrive! 
 
The raindrop patterns on the swimming pool are so hypnotic - probably my favourite time to sit outside (under a covered space) in summertime to watch. I also think Gaura ‘Whirling Butterflies” might looks it’s absolute best during a summer storm 💦 
 
Landscape Design by Melanie Rekola @ladylandscape

Save this list if you’re planning a Winter Garden ❄️ 

I think some perennials look their best in winter. Brown is a beautiful colour that doesn’t get nearly enough appreciation 🤎🤎
 
Its mind boggling that winter gardens aren’t more celebrated here in Canada, especially since winter lasts soooo long! 

Here are a few of my favourite’s perennials for winter interest – swipe to see them in winter versus summer. Take a guess at which each is before you swipe!
 
1: Wild Bergamot / Monarda fistulosa (Ontario Native)

2. Perennial sunflower , or Sunchoke/ Helianthus tuberosus (Ontario Native)

3. Miscanthus sinensis

4. Teasle / Dipsacus fullonum

5. Black-eyed Susan / Rudbeckia hirta (Ontario Native)
 
 By leaving perennials standing in fall instead of cutting them back, it benefits you (winter gardens have so much beauty) and local wildlife (food and shelter for birds, insects, and other small creatures.)
 
Do you have a favourite perennial for winter interest? Looking for some new inspiration! 
 
Landscape Design by Melanie Rekola @ladylandscape

Have your eyes been opened? 😳
 
Natural Christmas trees are grown as a crop for 8-10 years & during that time they produce oxygen, filter the air, sequester carbon, provide habitat for wildlife, & help mitigate climate change. Plus, they are fully biodegradable & can be ground into usable mulch
 
In stark contrast, artificial trees (& plastic “garland”) are usually made from PVC & nonrecyclable by most municipalities. They take 500 years to decompose in a landfill! During their often unregulated, overseas production the PVC releases cancer-causing chemicals called dioxins into the atmosphere. Dioxins are considered highly toxic & dangerous to human health as per the WHO.
 
Fake PVC trees also contains phthalates, which have been linked to birth defects, hormone disruption & miscarriages. Plus, they often contain lead! Lead exposure is associated with many health issues in adults including kidney damage, high blood pressure & reproductive issues but what’s worse is that young children are considered the most susceptible to its effects. These effects can include learning problems, lower IQ, slowed growth, hearing loss & anemia.
 
I know many of us already have an artificial tree, and it that case please be careful to wash your hands after you put it up & take it down. Especially limit the access under the tree to small children (as per the Journal of Environmental Health). And when that tree is no longer useful to you, make the right choice for your health & the environment – choose a real tree! But if the cost and logistics are an issue, cut some branches & make a “Christmas bush” instead. Yes, a bush form is non-traditional, but who says a Christmas tree must be pointy? Let’s embrace change for the better!

Welcome to Three Feathers Terrace! @threefeathersterrace 
 
This year I had the pleasure of working on the wedding gardens for this newly opened and totally amazing wedding venue!! 

Swipe for more of the construction phase and a couple of the garden plans. But FYI, working in 1”= 30’ scale its not so easy to see. Better to go in person once its all planted, and head over to @threefeathersterrace for its completed current state 🙌
 
The first photo is of the existing entryway. A gorgeous Allie lined with lovely White Pines – this area is 350’ long and will be filled with all-white gardens. Choosing perennials that will do well under pines is no small feat! Plants like Helleborus, Aquilegia, Astilbe, Peony, Anemone (both spring and fall flowering) , Fern and Hosta will all do well here. Definitely the largest gardens I’ve planned to date. Can’t you just imagine a beautiful couple being drawn by horse and carriage up this entry space? 
 
The connection from the indoors to the outdoors was top of mind for this project and you can see why with so many huge and beautiful windows! Lots of Incrediball Hydrangea will grace this incredible, passive structure 🤍🤍

The experienced owners had great vision and foresight to make this wedding venue beautiful, functional, and usable in all seasons with features such as several indoor/outdoor spaces, a large freestanding outdoor fireplace and a timeless stone Moongate – the perfect place to take one’s vows. 

Surrounding the Moongate and seating space the frothy, all-white gardens continue and white flowering trees such as Serviceberry, Snowdrift Crabapple , Northern Catalpa and Horse Chestnut will dot the surrounding landscape.
 
Its such a huge undertaking and many skilled tradespeople helped make this happen (like the patio/hardscape work by @firestonelandscaping and awesome stone Moongate by @tylermcleod86  just to name a couple). So proud to say I played a part here!
 
Garden Design by Melanie Rekola @ladylandscape

Time for a reintroduction 🙌
 
Hi I’m Melanie Rekola - independent Landscape Designer serving Central Ontario - welcome to my page! 
 
I have a passion for clean lines, functional but beautiful outdoor spaces combined with lots of trees & flowers to support our local wildlife systems.  Seeing that you’re here, I assume these things are also important to you ! 

I’ve been working in this field for more that 20 years & niching down to offer only Modern/ Scandinavian style garden & landscapes design was the best thing I ever did for my business. I think specialization is the key to becoming an expert in one area, rather than dabbling in many but a master of none. 
 
Landscape design covers so much more than gardens, but plants do have a great influence on my design work and style. I firmly believe that backyards without plantings are cold, inhospitable, and unwelcoming spaces.  In every home I’ve ever owned I’ve created huge gardens where I’ve tried and tested so many plants. Using my own garden as a test lab gives me great insight into how these plants perform and a lot of insight into the wildlife that lives within our gardens. I truly enjoy passing on my hands-on knowledge of plants & pollinators to my clients.
 
Since the start of pandemic, the home improvement industry saw a great uptick in sales, my business included. I’ve been steadily booking design work about 6months in advance since 2020 & I’m so flattered and appreciative for all of you that patiently waited for me! Instagram has been a huge part of my professional growth - I’ve met so many amazing clients & friends here. Recently I’ve seen some of them have their account hacked like: 

@down2earth_official 
@stonecreationsoflongislandinc @stcbuildersindooroutdoor

Its so sad.  What I hear across the board from all of them is, they didn’t have enough photos of themselves posted for Instagram to be able to verify the account was theirs. So – if you want to protect your account post some photos of yourself! This was my motivation for todays  post - shown here in my happy place! 🌳

Hardy Hydrangea list + troubleshooting + pruning tips
 
Hydrangeas are very likely the MOST popular flowering shrub worldwide. Many varieties are low maintenance & long blooming but only if you choose the correct types!
 
I focus here on the no-fail types because many of the alluring macrophylla/Lace cap kinds seen in nurseries don’t often perform well in the garden. Yes, they may survive and put out lots of foliage – but they often don’t bloom. And if they do, the bloom period is super short as they need the ideal controlled amount of moisture/conditions which is unsustainable in most garden situations.
 
What hydrangeas are very reliable & long blooming here in the North? Hydrangea arborescence and Hydrangea paniculata in all the luscious varieties of each! All hardy zones 3 -7 (and sometimes 8) . A few of my favourite’s shown are:
 
Hydrangea paniculata ‘Zinfin Doll’
Hydrangea paniculata ‘Limelight’
 Hydrangea arborescence Abeto / Incrediball
 Hydrangea paniculata Renhy ‘Vanilla Strawberry’
Hydrangea arborescence / Annabelle
 
All these types don’t need any chemical fertilization to bloom spectacularly! All you need is a good, heathy soil base, hopefully with some compost amendment. For extra-good measure, some natural mycorrhizae and bone meal should be added at planting time – it’s really that simple! 
 
The best time to prune these hydrangeas is in very early spring before the leaves emerge. Falling snow won’t hurt them as isn’t often compacted & heavy like shoveled snow is – but of course there are circumstances where freezing rain occurs & that can be heavy. If some branches break during winter, it’s still ok for the plant. I still suggest leaving the flower heads on. But never shovel snow on or prune more than 1/3rd off any woody shrub per year for optimal health. When I get questions about why these types of hydrangeas aren’t blooming or that stems are weak its usually because someone pruned them to the ground or at the wrong time. 
 
Save this list for tons of Hydrangea enjoyment in your future!

Snow’s back! ❄️ 

Some people worry about the snows affects on plant-life - but snow actually has lots of insulating benefits for their root systems. It is good for the forest and your garden! It’s just part of natures seasonal cycle. 

I know a lot of you don’t love winter like I do , but I hope you can still appreciate all this winter forest beauty. Looks like it might be a white Christmas this year!

Cheers to a brand New Year 🥂
 
Starting off 2023 right with this garden courtyard design! There’s something so comforting and nestled about sitting within a walled garden. 

Garden walls give structure and keep the courtyard cozy and protected from wind - which is especially nice when sitting around an outdoor fireplace. 

If the elevations work out, the gardens behind are raised offering a unique vantage point. Often front-of-the-garden perennials are only viewed from above yet this way they take on a completely new look to appreciate!
 
If you’ve missed my posting lately its for a very good reason – I promise!  I relocated houses and it took time to get organized after. First time I’ve taken 2 weeks off for Insta posting since 2019! Anyhow, I’m back in the swing and so excited about the Landscape Design work of 2023.
 
If you’re needing any help with your dream backyard or front yard design, I still have spots from the end of June onward. Please get in touch soon to secure your spot!

Never too soon to start thinking about planter design! Swipe for 6 of my favourites 🌸 
 
Garden planters are often an afterthought within Landscape Design, but I like to incorporate them within my plans as I prefer large ones.
 
Yes, a grouping a smaller planters can have a similar visual weight as a hefty one, but the larger the plant pot, the less you’ll need to water it. And I like less maintenance when it comes to containers!
 
What I love about container gardening is that you can switch up the plants every year if you like – or even use perennials, shrubs, and trees for a more permanent planting arrangement if you’re thrifty. The trick to planting non-annuals in planters is to pick plants in zones 2 or lower than your current planting zone so the can handle the difficult freeze/thaw cycles that affect them. This way you have a much better chance of the plants surviving winter with ease.
 
Once you plant anything in a contained space its life is completely dependent on you! You cannot rely on nature to water & feed your planter plants. I suggest always starting with specific container soil & some organic, slow-release fertilizer like bone meal , compost, and mycorrhizae soil conditioner. Always have an unclogged drainage hole within the pot & stick your fingers in the soil before you water to access moisture content – overwatering kills plants quicker than underwatering!
 
Planter pics shown:
 
1: Modern Meadow (White Echinacea, Coreopsis, Pennsylvania sedge + spurge)
2: Cosmos
3: Gaura
4: River Birch
5: Dahlia
6: Zinnia
 
I usually plant simply with just one plant type per pot! Except for my most recent planter “Modern Meadow”. Which one is your fav?
 
Landscape Design by Melanie Rekola @ladylandscape

The Bridge 🙌
 
This is a unique project I had the pleasure of working on some years ago. The one and only time where a bridge feature was involved!
 
I was brought in to consult with these clients during the complete rebuild/construction of their home on this Old Mississauga property. 

They expressed a desire for an attention-grabbing front yard fit to match their luxurious new home, shade gardens to thrive under the extensive tree canopy, a new driveway/parking layout and a way to deal with a wet seasonal trench that would form every spring. I suggested a drive riverbed to address the spring ponding, with a driveway bridge over it on the first draft and they said YES!
 
This design project spanned a few years and after my work was done, it still needed architectural planning and engineering for the bridge feature. It was so rewarding to see it finally completed after the initial idea so long before. 
 
Swipe to see move views – The last one is a snippet of the extensive bulb gardens in springtime, I need to get back here and get more springtime photos!

I don’t typically work on homes of this caliber and it’s definitely one I’m proud of. Do you think this bridge suits this fine home?

What pool size should you choose? 🤔 
 
Long ago, most homeowners would choose the biggest pool they could fit into their backyard, but this is an old way of thinking.
 
When considering outdoor living space versus pool space – know that even if you use your pool everyday - the outdoor living spaces with be used more! 

Alfresco spaces are extensions of your indoor spaces & with proper planning can make if feel like you have double the living area for half the year!  Lots of consideration needs to put into both areas.
 
For most residential backyards with a pool,  I feel there needs to be comfortable seating spaces for both sun/shade, a place for outdoor dining/cooking, sun loungers & space for gardens. 
 
20+ years ago almost everyone would choose a 20’ x 40’ pool but things have changed a lot since then! Swimming pools can be almost any size, and they keep getting smaller. Furthermore, vinyl lined & concrete pool interiors are customizable with fun tanning ledges and alluring full width steps. Thankfully, gone are the days of pool ladders and white plastic-look steps – the customization of a pool interior within the pool footprint offers a lux, uninterrupted look! Modern swimming pools are meant to not only to be enjoyed by the swimmer but equally for the viewer.
 
Things that will dictate your pool size and features? The backyard size & budget of course but also how you’d like to use your pool such a plunging or fitness swimming, diving, or pool sports. Your chosen landscape designer or pool professional can help!
 
You might notice that I almost always show rectangular pools here and that’s because a clean, rectilinear shape is both modern and classic! It will never go out of style. Pool design is also so much more than just plunking a rectangle on a plan with a patio surround – pools steps & features play an important role in the overall function & beauty of the design!
 
Swipe for the small pools collection 💦
 
What does your dream pool look like?

Why garden with NATIVE & POLLINATOR plant species?
 
To support local ecosystems, increase biodiversity, & provide food/shelter to countless wild creatures! 
 
Will you be including indigenous & pollinator-friendly plants in your garden plans this year? Together we can make a difference!
 
Nature is at its tipping point - Habitat loss, climate change & chemical use are having disastrous effects on our dear Mother Earth. But we can help by making our own gardens into a lifeline for wildlife.
 
It is said that to make a solid impact we need to have 86% native plantings in our outdoor spaces. Maybe this sound daunting – but I assure you – native plants are also fantastically beautiful! Indigenous plants are the foundation:  vital to local eco systems as they evolved together to support each over a very long period of time. 

Native plants are also tough, resilient, and specifically adapted to their natural environment and don’t require any extra babying as many exotic varieties do.
 
I’ve recently moved homes and my new gardens will be the recommended 86% native – I can’t wait to show you how gorgeous an indigenous garden can be!
 
Please share – we CAN make a change together 💚

The veggie garden entrance – swipe to see what’s on the other side 👀 
 
This project is dear to my heart because it uses something practical and often concealed as a focal point instead. Veggie gardens don’t have to be hidden away from sight – with proper planning they can be beautiful!
 
Features that make this food garden pretty are the custom black, powder coated planters, whimsical arbours for beans to climb over and the heavy-on-the-flowers pollinator gardens surrounding. Pollinators and veggie gardens go hand in hand as by giving them an all-season food source you’ll get a better yield out of your food crops. 
 
The fire space sits right in the middle of the food garden and offers a glimpse of the luxurious, Scandinavian style pool/outdoor living space beyond 🙌
 
Lots of progression has been made on this project in the past year – super excited to show you real “after” photos of it instead of just renderings!

Pocket gardens 💚
 
I love showing this project as an example to new clients. I think it proves how important gardens are to the overall esthetic and enjoyment of a backyard space.
 
Certainly, you could just make this whole space patio along the back of the home and forgo the planting pockets altogether - but it would not be nearly as pretty. Pocket gardens are the perfect spot to place a focal feature like this water bowl or even a piece of garden art if you prefer too. 

Planting pockets also reduce heat island effect making these spaces cooler, naturally. If given the choice and space is available, I would never place a patio right against the home without a garden buffer in-between!
 
Also loving this black pergola’s location. By placing it central to the outdoor living space, it’s so inviting and looks great from every angle and in every season, even from inside the home!
 
Landscape Design by Melanie Rekola @ladylandscape

Lofty Loggia & Japanese Maple goals realized at this old Mississauga property 🙌
 
I think design work for new landscapes is easier than designing for backyard renovations – but backyard redo’s happen often. 

This existing concrete pool had to stay in place but received a well-deserved interior refresh – the pool wall with water feature scuppers,  the circular spa, patio , loggia and planting pockets were all new additions to the project.
 
There were extensive trees present and all were kept other than 3! The mature Japanese Maples were an important, sculptural focal point here not easily replaced – so important to the overall feel of the space. They have a gnarly, mature beauty not often seen in smaller trees.
 
I very rarely spec Japanese Maples where I am North of Toronto as they aren’t very hardy here, but I definitely can appreciate them in the south.  I think a good alternative to Japanese Maple for northern areas zone 3 and 4 is Pagoda Dogwood / Cornus alternifolia and its super tough – also a native plant to Canada and the US.
 
Though this project is a bit different than my usual clean, straight lines I’m glad some of the existing features stayed. Given the cost of a brand-new swimming pool it made no sense to obliterate the existing one. And mature trees should always be kept where possible – so much better to work around them (most of the time) rather that wait for years and years for them to establish and get to the size you’d like! 

As it is said – the best time to plant a tree is 5 years ago. The second-best time is ASAP!
 
Landscape Design by Melanie Rekola @ladylandscape

My Moongate obsession 🌙 
 
The Moongate concept has been around for a long time, but you hardly ever see them. I believe my fascination with them goes back about 3-4 years. Swipe to see a few concepts, and a real life Moongate installed with a couple of progress pics too 🙌
 
Garden arbours in general make a wonderful focal point. I find these perfect circle varieties fit very well with chalet style homes and their steeply pitched roofs. They also fit perfectly in modern outdoor spaces because of their simple, geometric shape!
 
If you want a Monngate garden sculpture of your very own, it must be custom-made by a metal fabricator. You can choose between Corten Steel (also called weathering steel) or they can be powder coated aluminum in a colour of your choice! They are HEAVY so shipping needs to be considered as well as installation as they need to be set in concrete to make them secure. 
 
Looking forward to showing you more Moongate installations this year! Do you want one too? 
 
Landscape Design by Melanie Rekola @ladylandscape

Plant Dahlias for a long season of cutting flowers 🌸 
 
Even if you don’t cut bouquets, Dahlias are still worth growing as they flower so profusely. Yes, they are high maintenance (if you live in planting zones 7 or lower) in that you must lift the tubers and overwinter them in a cool place indoors to plant again the following year. 

To me, this is so worth the effort as you don’t have to purchase new throw-away plants every year. Plus, you’ll get more tubers each year to plant and give away to friends too!
 
I started my Dahlia tubers indoors in April last year and planted them out in May after the frost date. I had an abundance of flowers and soooo many bouquets from June – frost.  If you love cut flowers this is this is the perfect addition to a cutting garden – they last forever in a vase.
 
Planning on have Dahlias in your garden this year? If you have a favourite variety, please let me know below!

Garden lighting 101 💡 
 
Often forgotten yet sorely missed - of all the things that get crossed off a backyard Wishlist due to budget constraints, landscape lighting seems to be the first.
 
Professional landscape lighting does have cost involved, but thankfully most residential backyards don’t require much! And you can (and should) supplement with some inexpensive solar lanterns and string lights for a layered, ambient effect.
 
Landscape lighting should be subtle IMO. I see so many over lit outdoor spaces, I can’t possibly imagine relaxing in an area where every tree and stair is brightly lit creating a feeling like a runway or stage. Here’s what you should do:
 
✨ Add multiple styles of lighting, not JUST the up lighting of trees. Lighting can be added to steps, walls, and even in water.

✨ Wherever possible, use downlighting instead of up to create a moonlighting effect that doesn’t disrupt the night sky with light pollution. A nice thing about downlighting is, that it can create stunning shadow effects of foliage on patios and paths when placed high up in a tree.

✨ Even in a formal setting, don’t light every tree and step. Lighting every second or third one is often more than enough and will still give formality to spaces such as these.

✨ Don’t forget to add white to your garden pallet! White/light coloured flowers, furniture/textiles and hardscape materials glow and amplify all outdoor lighting. 

✨ Choose warm white light and put your lights on a timer so that your landscape lighting doesn’t disrupt the important work of night pollinators such as moths and beetles.

✨ LED is the energy efficient way to go. Yes, they cost more upfront, but they last a very long time and require no maintenance. They save money in the long term 🙌
 
Landscape lighting sets the scene for amazing garden drama that can completely transform an outdoor space in the evening! Don’t forget about the lights 💡

Who’s ready for spring? 🌸
 
I think early bloomers are a must-have for every garden. After a long winter there is nothing better than seeing your outdoor space spring to life! 

It’s not just the flowers that add so much pop – its all the fresh and plump green foliage that goes along with them. Because who wants to stare at sticks and bare soil until May? Spring flowering perennials and bulbs to the rescue! Start your garden’s beauty off right and as early as possible 🙌
 
Here’s a collection of some of my favs – all varieties shown are squirrel proof too. 

 1 - This blue and white mix of Muscari dazzles for 2 months! Also love this clump of snowdrops / Galanthus elwesii that sparkles in the background.

2 & 3 - Helleborus, a commonly know harbinger of spring that no garden should be without! And its not just for their gorgeous flowers, their foliage is beautiful too and lasts all season.

4 - Mini Daffodils. So many types are available but I like these little trumpet shaped ones in a soft yellow that pairs so easily with other colours.

5 - Pasque flower / Anemone patens is sometimes called Prairie Crocus and this north American native has pretty flowers with woolly stems/foliage offering a unique texture. An underused plant imo!

6 - Winter Aconite has delicate,  yellow blossoms and leaves that appear so early. Also an underused plant and not seen nearly enough!
 
What flowers are your favourites for spring?

What are Keystone species & why do we need them 🤔 
 
A Keystone specie is one that fills a critical niche within its native ecosystem that no other specie can. A Keystone specie can be found anywhere within the food web-  all the way from top Carnivore down to bottom soil decomposer – a plant, animal, insect, bacteria, or fungi can all be Keystone & they all have a disproportionally strong influence on others within their environment.
 
By including native Keystone plants in your garden, you’ll have the greatest impact on your local ecosystems. One of the key attributes of these plants is that they support insects! And yes, supporting pollinators is super important but another important aspect is that so many other creatures need insects as a food source. For example, if you want birds in your yard you need insects available for them to feed their young. Baby birds depend on protein rich insects to survive.
 
Swipe to see the list of Keystone perennial plants for your Ontario garden – but if you live elsewhere, you can easily find out which Keystone plants are critical to your area.
 
Native asters such as Sky blue/ Symphyotrichum oolentangiense and New England / Symphyotichum novae-angliae

Wild Bergamot / Monarda fistulosa

Black eyed Susan / rudbeckia hirta

Blazing Star/ Liatris spicata (photo by Doreen Wynja @eyeofthelady2 ) 

Goldenrod/ Solidago canadensis
 
If you want to take this a step further, consider planting these native Ontario Keystone Trees!
 
Pin Cherry, White Oak, Red Maple (not the kind with red leaves FYI) , Sugar Maple and the many native Willows such as Black, Shining, Bebb’s, Sandbar and Pussy.
 
If you want to know what happens when a Keystone top predator is removed from an ecosystem do a quick search about the ecological collapse that happened at Yellowstone park when they “removed” their wolves. 🥲
 
Save the list if you want to support nature in your Ontario garden!

Growing Cosmos 🌸– everything you need to know!
 
Beautiful Cosmos bipinnatus is an easy annual to grow – offering so much but requires so little! 

When grown from seed you’ll get flowers in about 7 weeks and they’ll continue flowering profusely until first frost – that’s a lot impact for only a few dollars spent in seed, I think! 
 
Cosmos prefers lean soil and drier conditions once established. If the soil is too rich or if it gets too much water, all you’ll get is leaves and not so many flowers.
 
I think any garden is better with addition of some easy annual flowers like these! So many varieties available and here are my current favs 🌸
 
Apolla White (shorter variety)
Cupcakes and Saucers (taller variety)
Apollo Pink (shorter variety)
Apricot Lemonade (shorter variety) – Growing this for the 1rst time this year! I’m super exited! 
 
If starting Cosmos seeds indoors, the best time to start is 6 weeks before your frost date.  You can use almost anything to sow them in as a soil container (such as an old yogurt or cottage cheese container) . 

Though technically you could grow them is seed trays you would have to transplant them once they outgrow them – so I think it easier to just start with a deeper container from the start. 

Alternatively, you can direct sow seed in the garden after the frost date, but know that you’ll have to wait for flowers.
 
Though these aren’t a North American native, pollinators love these stunning, nectar rich flowers! If left to go to seed the birds will eat them too.  They sometime even sow themselves and appear the following year with no intervention from you. Plus, you can save the seeds! 
 
Are you growing Comos this year? I’m starting mine first week in April – one week today!

Time to prune your hardy Hydrangeas! Late winter / early spring is the ideal time. If you prune later you’ll get small, sub-par blossoms.
 
Hardy Hydrangeas are the low maintenance, no-fail types like Hydrangea paniculata & Hydrangea arborescens and I only recommend hardy hydrangeas as they bloom profusely and reliably! Why be disappointed by those fussy & untrustworthy Hydrangea macrophyllas?

🌸 Limelight l Hydrangea paniculata ‘Limelight’

🌸Zinfin Doll / Hydrangea paniculate ‘ Zinfin Doll”

🌸Vanilla Strawberry / Hydrangea paniculate ‘Rehny’

Honorable mention - Oakleaf / Hydrangea quercifolia (not shown)

 Save this no-fail hardy Hydrangea list! 

Never prune more than 1/3 of any woody shrub at a time and please WAIT to cut back perennials & grasses, and don’t rake out leaves until its 10 degrees Celsius for 10 days consecutively. Many pollinators are overwintering in our gardens and haven’t woken up yet from hibernation 🐝 🦋

What value do garden arbours bring to an outdoor space? I think a whole lot!
 
I incorporate garden arbours into to my design work a lot. They add punctuation to entryways, can separate garden rooms, add interest in wintertime and are a wonderful place to grow vines! 

They act as delightful focal points and practically beckon onlookers to explore. Walking through almost feels like you’re stepping through a portal.
 
Planted here are (American Bittersweet/ Celastrus scandens and Trumpet Creeper /Campsis radicans) and it took a long time for them to really take off. Swipe to see the arbour and growth progressions through the years with the naked arbour 6 years ago at the end 😳
 
I knew both these vines were garden bullies right from the start, but as they are contained a planting pocket, I knew they’d work well here. Learning to control the Trumpet was a bit of learning curve - I was just so happy to finally have it full and thriving I was afraid to prune too much! But learn I did – I’d take off all small thin branches in early spring leaving only the strong stems and branching. During the summer I’d prune a few more times to keep it tidy – totally worth it to me!
 
I wish good looking garden arbours could be found easily in a prefab construction, but I haven’t found any great one yet. Custom is the way for these, but you’ll also get the exact dimensions and style you want. For reference, this arbour is 8’ H x 6’ W and 2’ depth.
 
Planning on adding an arbour to your garden? Will you grow vines or leave it bare? Either way looks good!

TREE FACTS YOU DIDN’T KNOW ABOUT 🙌
 
Trees don’t just get to a certain height then stop growing – they grow until they die.
 
Most trees don’t die from old age , instead they succumb to disease or human intervention.
 
Tree staking is not often necessary, but if stakes are present, they should only be on for 1 year maximum. Otherwise, you risk killing the tree.
 
The average lifespan of residential, planted tree is generally under 10 years because when we move houses the new homeowners remove them. I wish it weren’t true, but this is a cold, hard fact.
 
I hope you learned something new! Welcoming all tree related questions 👇

Perennial gardens 🆚 shrub gardens 
 
If you drive around your neighbourhood, you’ll notice a lot of people prefer mostly shrub-based gardens. This is likely because they’re lower maintenance, but I think they lack the beauty, airiness and seasonal changes that perennial gardens bring.
 
Shrub gardens look pretty much the same throughout a lot of the growing season - maybe some blooming at some point - but not nearly the exciting spring to fall flowering that a perennial based garden can. And all theses flowers do more than just excite the senses – choose wisely and you’ll be provided food sources for hungry pollinators all season long.
 
To be clear, there are many beautiful garden shrubs out there and I don’t think you should exclude them! I just think that gardens optimally need to be biodiverse and include woody plants (like trees and shrubs) and perennials too. These are best for beauty (IMO) and for the earth. 

I’m sure I’ll still have to design some super simple shrub gardens for clients this summer but I’m always hoping to change some minds. Because you know what? Biodiversity is cool 😎

Does a garden require edging? 🤔 
 
I don’t think garden edging is completely necessary, but it does make a garden lower maintenance when said garden touches lawn. By installing hard edging, you’ll never have to recut that garden edge again!
 
Cutting a garden edge that is linear can be difficult to get perfectly straight too. But if you don’t mind that extra edging work, slope the garden soil away from the lawn cut so that the grass roots don’t have any soil to root in, towards the garden. This will make the garden edge last longer.
 
Metal edging like this Corten steel is my complete favourite! I love how slim the profile is and its super strong. Another option is a low, stone garden edge which can also look great! However, I strongly feel that plastic edging should be avoided at all costs as it just never looks good and cheapens the look.

Faux infinity pool – details matter!
 
Most of us have heard of the term “infinity pool”, but what exactly does it mean? 

Also called “zero edge pools”, these are swimming pools where water flows over one or more edges producing a sense that the water has no boundary. But this effect can also be produced with a see-through acrylic edge, instead 🙌
 
If you scroll through the images, you’ll see the acrylic pool edge here is only a few inches in height,  but the effect is the same as a true infinity pool when viewed from the other other side!
 
What are the benefits of an acrylic edge over a zero-edge pool? Depending on many factors, they will cost less as the pool mechanics will be different and you won’t have the heat loss, extra electricity costs and evaporation associated with a true infinity edge. They also take up less room as you won’t need the reservoir for water recovery at the end of the pool. Just know both types are expensive as these are luxury pools. 
 
My clients here chose the acrylic edge option as they wanted to save the tree right in the middle of the acrylic edge and the reservoir associated with an infinity pool would have forced them have to remove the tree. They chose to keep the tree as priority! 🌳

10 native North American plant ideas for your garden
 
Pollinator gardens are a big buzz word currently, and yes – it IS important to plant flowers for all season food to feed them - but what’s more important is to plant native species of your area.  These offer the best nectar sources, offer host plant opportunities for their young, and are the 100% best for your local pollinators as they have evolved together to support each other over a millennium.
 
All of these perennials are native to my Canadian garden, but lots of the same species are native to areas of the USA too. Tried and tested in my own garden, they are all worthy additions! Here’s the list below:
 
1. Wild Bergamot / Monarda fistulous
2. Purple Coneflower / Echinacea purpurea
3. Hoary Vervain/ Verbena stricta
4. Greyheaded coneflower / Ratibida pinnata
5. Joe-pye weed (big and beautiful - likes lots of moisture)
6. Sunchokes (good for large properties as it can take over)
7. Blue Vervain/ Verbena hastata
8. Obeidient plant / Physostegia virginiana (can be a bully, better in a contained area or large space)
9. New England aster / Symphyotrichum novae-angliae
10. Virginia Bluebells / Mertensia virginica (actually a spring ephemeral , but completely worth planting for these gorgeous blue flowers!)
 
Don’t forget to save the list!

Sky pergolas are structures similar to a classic pergola - except they don’t have any slats on the top portion that a typical pergola would. 

They act much like a garden arbour in the sense that their purpose isn’t so much for function (other than a spot for vines to climb, hang string lights or to support hanging chairs). Some people might worry that the pool wall with waterfalls would hide the pool view when seated under the sky pergola here , but as the wall is the same height as a typical chair - while lying in the daybeds or swinging in the hanging chairs the pool is in plain view. Food garden tips ✨
 
I think veggie gardens can look lovely with a good design! If possible, plan them in a spot that you’ll see regularly as when they’re tucked away out of sight, they’re easy to neglect.
 
Here, a pollinator garden was planting adjacent to the food garden. By creating a constant food source from spring to fall for pollinators it makes them stick around and makes the veggie garden up to 30% more productive!
 
Notice the marigolds planted in the raised beds? They do more that just look pretty – the strong scent of marigolds deters many of the unwanted insects that eat our food plants. They also feed the nearby pollinators and are edible themselves adding an appetizing punch of colour to your salads or as a garnish.
 
Also worth noting is the Moongate entrance to the veggie garden – adding a focal point such as an arbour makes you want to visit the edible gardens more often 🙌
 
A few years ago, I did an lettuce experiment: I started lettuce seeds indoors to transplant into my veggie garden after the frost date and also sowed the same lettuce seeds directly in the garden. You know what? The seeds that I sowed directly ended up only about 2 weeks behind in size of the ones that I started 6 weeks previous! 

Therefore, I now ALWAYS sow lettuce seeds directly in the garden and sow a new row every two weeks for the entire growing season to ensure I have fresh lettuce the whole time. Direct sowing also works well with other veggies like peas, carrots, and some herbs.
 
Are you growing an edible garden this year?

Don’t throw away your pollinators ✌️
 
It’s so easy to be excited for spring and want to start your garden cleanup but please wait 🛑 
 
Many different pollinators such as bees and butterflies are hibernating in the old, dry plant stocks and leaves. By waiting until its 10 degrees Celsius / 50 degrees Fahrenheit for 10 days consecutively (including overnight temps) you’ll ensure they get enough time to wake up from hibernation, and ensure there’s enough plant life producing flowers to sustain them.
 
What can you do early outside without harming sleeping pollinators? Wash your decks and patios, rake your paths, and gently fluff the leaves in your garden but don’t remove them. By leaving your garden leaves in place they will decompose and feed your garden soil making it healthier. Natures way is always the best way – there’s no need to use chemical fertilizers.
 
Please spread the word - these little creatures can’t speak for themselves 🐝 🦋

Butterfly pics for Earth Day 🦋 
 
I’ve always felt a deep connection to the Earth/nature and when I first started on my journey in Landscape Design back in 2001 I had every intention to change the world. But what I found then was - people weren’t interested in gardens planned for nature in mind. 

I’ve had some dark years where I was forced to create (what I call) soul sucking backyard plans with barely a plant or tree is involved because that’s what people wanted – and I needed to be able to support myself financially. I became much more quiet about my feelings for the earth as it seemed no one wanted to listen.
 
Thankfully – those times are behind me, and I know many of you care like I do! I love Instagram for its ability to bring like-minded people together and it’s given me my voice back! 

Thank you for your support, thank you for reading my long cations and thank you for caring for the Earth 🌍 
 
A few Earth-friendly garden tips to share: 
 
Never use chemical fertilizers, or pesticides. Chemicals don’t deserve a home in our gardens. Chemical fertilizers often only focus on one part of the plant (like leaves or flowers) but don’t address the most important part of the plant – its roots. Natural fertilizers like bone meal feed plants in the proper balance as nature intended. Pesticides are even worse! Pesticides don’t care if they’re killing pollinators or mosquitos. Implement natural methods for the sake of the earth and your food source.
 
Never, ever use poison as “pest control” in your house or yard as poisons gets passed down the food chain. If you poison a mouse and a fox or owl eats it, they die too.
 
Implement regionally native plants in your gardens. Your native pollinators evolved specifically with these plants, and they need each other to survive.  Everyone has different thoughts on the percentage needed, but please plant as many as you can.
 
 Be kind to nature and it will give back to you 10fold✌️

My design process ✨ 
 
When I first visit a new design project location the design doesn’t just “pop into my head” at the first meeting. Lots of thought needs to be put into each new design after I’ve taken my photos/ measurements and imported everything in my design software.
 
I typically begin with placement of the largest item on the Wishlist, which is often a swimming pool. Then I add some standard furniture pieces and work on the patio/deck space and elevations so that it makes functional sense for outdoor living. I then loosely plan the garden spaces for optimum beauty, views, and screening. 

Each version of the drawing has more detail added. For example - there is no point listing each plant on the very first draft as it could all change!
 
Perhaps it sounds strange to consider outdoor furniture and traffic flow so early in planning, but I’ve learned that its necessary for a functional outdoor living experience. I can’t tell you how many times I’ve consulted to with a new client that had a pool and a basic patio put in but there’s is not enough space for loungers or a dining table.  Its so much better to plan for furniture – its talks the guesswork out how the space will be used and reduces wasted patio space (and therefore cost) too.

Water brings wildlife 💦
 
When we have a pond, a pool or water feature in our yard it comes with great responsibility to local wildlife. Water is even more important that food and sometimes wildlife is so desperate for it that they get trapped trying to get it.
 
What can we do to keep our pools and ponds safe for animals?
 
- I’ve found that by providing a shallow dish or two of water near this pond it provides birds and animals much safer access to water. Birds bathe in it constantly and also bring their babies. I always include a rock or two within the water bowl so that insects can safely get a drink as well. Mosquitoes are not a problem because I change/clean/fill the water ever two days.

- Within the pond I have floating plants and a floating “island” filled with water plants. I can’t tell you how many times I’ve found a mouse stranded on the island and watched birds & bees land on the plants to safely get a drink. The plants act as life preservers.

- Swimming pools can be death traps for many birds and animals. Its especially important to check your pool often in springtime as all the baby animals and fledgling birds are curious about water, without any experience.

- Trim any branches that overhang your pool, install a “frog log” beside your pool so that frogs/toads/mice can get out and add a “Toad ramp” to you pool skimmer so little creatures can safely exit.
 
Let’s keep wildlife safe ✌️

Landscape Design by Melanie Rekola @ladylandscape

My favourite thing about spring in Ontario? The ephemeral Trillium grandiflorum display ✨
 
This is a very healthy colony of native North American Trilliums and I keep its location secret because sometimes people pick them. And when you pick a Trillium flower, the plant may not survive.
 
Grown from seed, Trillium grandiflorum takes up to 2 years to germinate and even another 7 to bloom from there! This is why we cannot pick them if we want Trillium flowers in our future. 

Luckily I’ve noticed several nurseries selling them in recent years, so rather than picking Trilliums you can plant them to enjoy year after year. Just know they are costly to purchase due to their long germination rate.  Still worth it, I think!
 
Some fun Trillium facts:
 
• The seeds are dispersed primarily by ants
 
• They’re a favourite food of White-Tailed Deer
 
• There are 5 types of native Trillium found in Ontario and 38 spread throughout the USA – but I think Grandiflorum is the prettiest.
 
Why not plant native Trilliums instead of Daffodils in your garden? They are just as pretty if not more so 🌸

Adding Annuals 🌸
 
I think most perennial gardens benefit from the addition of annual flowering plants. It is the very nature of annuals to pump out as many flowers as they can during the summer/fall season, adding lots of garden interest. 

I love classic garden flowers like these pretty Cosmos bipinnatus and I deadhead mine regularly to keep the flowers coming.  I let them go to seed in September to feed the birds and also so I can collect some seeds to start again next year. 
 
Here in Canada, Cosmos are not an invasive species, but beware they are in some parts of southeast USA, Africa, Asia, Central America, and the Pacific Islands.
 
Annual flowers are especially important when a garden is in its early stages of maturity. Pretty annual flowers can fill in all the gaps while waiting for to perennials to mature and provide supplemental food for pollinators too! 
 
Cosmos bipinnatus is VERY easy to frow from seed and they’re inexpensive too! If you’ve never grown flowers from seed this is a great starter plant.
 
Are you growing Cosmos this year?

Our gardens are a lifeline for nature, & we need to include plants that insects can actually use! 
 
Native, straight species are always best for insects/wildlife but finding native plants for sale can be a real challenge.
 
So, which cultivated plant traits affect insect use negatively? 
 
🛑 Changing a plant with green leaves to red and purple – These discourage insect use.
🛑 Changing a flowers colour, size & shape often reduces insect use. 

Sometimes the insects can’t even get to the pollen or nectar due to so many doubled petals.
 
What traits don’t affect insect use?
 
💚Variegation
💚Increased berry size
💚Increased disease resistance
💚More compact growth
💚Enhanced fall colour
 
Cultivars are often propagated by cloning, offering no genetic mutations which means no adaptability to climate change & what’s even sadder is that many are sterile. 

Even from an esthetic view, I think through hybridization our garden plants have lost a lot of their natural & beautiful delicacy!
 
Ideally our gardens should have at least 70% native species, & I know this is a daunting number for many. Try to include as many as you can, replace traditional lawn, increase biodiversity, & replace invasive species as these escape our gardens and further hurt our natural forests & ecosystems.
 
With so many species at risk of extinction worldwide creating a pollinator friendly & sustainable garden could not be more important than it is right now. We owe it to our planet and our future - please help me spread the word ✌️

The landscape design mistakes I see most often? Skinny garden beds, skinny paths and not including enough green space to balance the home and hardscape.
 
Paths should be a minimum of 4’ and wider still if they are long for function and the correct scale balance.
 
Garden beds against a home should be at least 4’ wide and approximately 1/3 the height of the home for proper scale. There are some instances where I’ll create a 2.5’ bed in a backyard where things are very tight , but that is my absolute minimum. There needs to be enough space to create an effective composition and so that plants can thrive!
 
Sometimes its hard to convince others to leave room for gardens and trees when properties are small – but I strongly believe that any outdoor space without plants is cold, unwelcoming, and inhospitable. Agree or disagree?

Planting just one variety of Lilac / Syringa spp. isn’t enough. By planting early, mid and late blooming varieties you’ll get beautiful blossoms for 6+ weeks 🌸

Here are some examples.
 
Early Blooming: Syringa vulgaris ‘Charles Joly’
Mid blooming: Syringa vulgaris ‘Monge’ or ‘Firmament’
Late Blooming: Syringa x prestoniae ‘Miss Canada’ and ‘Donld Wyman’
 
Lilacs are tough, long-lived trees that are small enough to fit into most garden situations. Most only grow between 5’-12’ tall and they also make great cut flowers. Their large leaves emerge in early spring offering perfect privacy, which a big plus for many.
 
Syringa vulgaris is native to Eastern Europe, but it is not considered an invasive plant. You can plant Lilac along with other native plants in good conscience as they provide large amounts of nectar/pollen to feed bees, hummingbirds and butterflies too.  As always, try for at least 70% native and only 30% non-native plants in your garden as this is best for nature.
 
Perfect for planting zones 3-7, give it full sun, rich well draining soil and water to establish. Always prune 1/3 of the old wood and remove suckers right after flowering. They’re so simple to grow! 

They come in so many colours, but my favourite is White – what’s yours?

With all the beautiful plants to choose from that are native to your area, why would anyone ever plant an invasive species?
 
Let me introduce you to Canada Mayflower / Maianthemum canadense ! Native to Canada and the northeastern USA - this short, shade loving groundcover sports glossy leaves and pretty sprays of fragrant flowers and is a must-have for any shade garden. 

It blooms in May/June (hence the name) and the delicate flowers turn into red berries in fall that feed the birds and chipmunks.

White flowers are particularly lovely in shady spaces where they sparkle and glow with contrast. 
 
Why this native plant isn’t more readily available in most nurseries but invasive plants like Lily-of-the-Valley are,  I’ll never know. We can change this though – if we all ask our local nurseries to stock native plants and stop selling invasive species, we can make a change for the better.
 
For anyone that loves the look of invasive Lily-of-the-Valley / Convallaria majalis , Canada Mayflower is a wonderful alternative. Lily-of-the-Valley cannot be planted responsibly in your garden as it escapes into our forests and outcompetes our native plants.
 
Plant Canada Mayflower instead! 🤍

Yep, this modern pond & floating step is actually a steel & vinyl pool kit! 

The steel sides keep the step stable, the opening was filled with gravel and an overhanging natural stone slab was added to the top. The black pool/pond liner runs up the sides that support the step making it disappear, and adds to the floating effect ✨
 
Two scupper waterfalls add oxygen and recirculate the water through a UV filter to keep the water clean. Beneficial bacteria is added at the beginning of the season and then as needed during the summer. But the best and easiest small pond maintenance practice is, to remove 15% of the water and replace it weekly. Use that lovely, chlorine free water to hydrate your gardens!
 
Here we added floating water plants like native North American White Water Lily / Nymphaea odorata + annual Water Lettuce, plus a floating garden island filled with water loving plants. Having these types of plants in place is imperative to keep wildlife safe – they WILL come for a drink 💦

How do you feel about the colour orange?
 
Certainly, orange is a bold colour choice but when placed strategically with shades of purple flowering perennials, or even mixed with simple white,  its can be just the zip and zing a garden needs!
 
Please meet Geum ‘Totally Tangerine’ / Geum chiloense , a very floriferous perennial that blooms at exactly the time where many gardens lack interest – between the spring flowering bulbs and the burst of summer flowering perennials. 

It blooms from mid spring to early summer with delicate sprays of sorbet hued flowers that are so easy to pair. All this AND its scalloped leaves are mostly evergreen too!  It prefers part sun to sun, is hardy zones 4-7 and pollinators flock to these pretty flowers in abundance 🐝 
 
A nice thing about including a bit of orange or another bold colour in a garden is, you aren’t committed all season to it. Think of it a punch colour to look forward to,  it comes and goes seasonally and then you’re back to your favourite plant pallet for most of the season.
 
Geum chiloense is native to Chilli but it isn’t considered invasive in other parts of the world. For those in North America, there are other lovely plants in the genus that are native here such as Geum triflorum / Prairie Smoke which is grown more for its unique seed heads than flowers. Ive been planting this one recently and hope to have some good photos soon.

I am often approached for landscape design before a new home build is even begun, and I like it that way! It gives lots of time for back and forth regarding the design, so no hasty decisions need to be made.
 
I love a good Keyhole garden and wish these were included more often in home design.  I think the Serviceberry trees are a vital part of this garden plan – even though its a small space,  it needed trees IMO.

Your Hydrangea dreams CAN come true ✨
 
Incrediball Hydrangea / Hydrangea arborescence ‘Abetwo’ is a beautiful low maintenance shrub, hardy from zones 3-8  that blooms reliably and looks great for months! 

It grows well in part sun to full sun but will bloom better with more sunlight available. This variety has improved drought tolerance too! But the best part must be its strong stems that say upright and wont flop over. A rare attribute for plant with such huge 12” flower heads. 
 
If you’ve had problems getting your hydrangeas to bloom in past – you’re likely planting the wrong ones! I only plant the dependable varieties like Hydrangea arborescence & Hydrangea paniculata here in the North – there is just no point planting fussy Hydrangea macrophylla as they rarely bloom and if they do its not for long.
 
A few pruning tips:
 
🤍 Prune Incrediball Hydrangea every year in early spring before the new leaves emerge. This will stimulate your Hydrangea shrub to grow fuller and produce more flower heads. By pruning in early spring instead of fall, it helps protect the plant from cold temps and it will recover with new growth faster. Plus, you’ll get to enjoy the lovely bronze flower heads throughout fall and winter.

🤍 Always remove dead or sickly branches whenever you see them, at any time of year. This helps the plant resist diseases and stay healthy.

🤍 Never prune more than 1/3 of the entire shrub in one year. If you prune to the ground or more than 1/3 you will get reduced flower size and number, and the stems may be floppy.
 
Have you planting this amazing, dependable Hydrangea yet?

Flower ideas for the summer garden - North American native edition 🌸
 
Summer flowers are here! So many showy North American natives to choose from too. 

Here are some of my favourites, all listed are tough & drought tolerant after they establish.  I like the combination of all these together for their colours, shapes, & variety of flower sizes. 
 
🌸 Echinacea Pallida / Pale Conflower – Echinacea is probably the most well know native North American flower, but this Pale Coneflower with elegantly drooping petals & soft colouration is my favourite! This one blooms a little earlier than most varieties & blooms reliably in part shade. 

🌸 Monarda / Wild Bergamot – Such a fun flower shape, this one can spread out when its happy, but it pulls easily. Pinch it back in early May to keep it shorter & bushier with more flowers!

🌸 Echinacea purpurea / Purple Coneflower – Everyone’s favourite for its large, showy flowers. The longest blooming of the native north American Echinacea species.

🌸 Verbena hastata / Hoary Vervain – Flower spikes in the perfect shade of mid purple. Long blooming as the small flowerets open from the bottom to top.

🌸 Erigeron annuus / Daisy Fleabane – You’ll never find this in a nursery, but you might in an open field or roadside! Collect the seeds when you see it & spread it in the middle/ back of the border where you’d like to see these happy little flowers. Blooms for months & pairs well with others. 

🌸 Agastache foeniculum / Anise Hyssop – Bluish cast flower spikes bloom in abundance from summer through fall. Another variety that can do well with an early pinch back to keep it shorter.
 
 All listed are fantastic for pollinators & native to much of Canada and the USA, but as always - check to see how its listed for your state or province. You just never know if a certain plant is correct for the specific conditions of your area, even if its native to another area within your country.
 
Do you grow any of these? Which one is your fav?

Hey Lavender lover 🌸
 
Life is too short to live with old, woody Lavender that doesn’t bloom well! If you haven’t been pruning yours and it’s gotten woody,  its time for some replacements.
 
It’s always a good idea to grow some extra Lavender anyway as this is one of those plants that can perish after a wet winter or spring. If you’re growing Lavender, you must expect to occasionally lose a plant or two. This is why I never plant it in a row /as hedging here in the north. For best results, plant Lavender where it receives full sun, in lean to medium soil that’s well draining.
 
The two commonly grown of the hardier varieties of Lavandula are English Lavender/ Lavandula angustifolia and Munstead Lavender / Lavandula angustifolia ‘Munstead’. The only difference is that Munstead is a little shorter. Both are native to the Mediterranean, not invasive, hardy zones 5-9 and bloom profusely in summer.
 
Lavender is a wonderful herb for its aromatic qualities and edible too! To harvest, cut long stems that have half open flowers in the morning – then bundle, & hang to dry in a cool, dark place.
 
Happy Lavender season!

Focus on V E R B E N A 💜
 
Verbena known as Vervain are long blooming garden plants that offer high nectar yields for hungry pollinators.  Showing you 1 tender perennial & 2 North American native Vervain ideas for your garden pleasure!
 
💜 Verbena Bonariensis: My favourite Vervain for planters and for annual garden wow factor. Tall, slender stemmed & airy, clusters of small purple bubble flowers appear from spring – frost and blooms its head off without deadheading! Perfect for full sun to part shade, fast growing Tall Vervain is only hardy in planting zones 7- 11 but still a worthy addition even if its not perennial in your area. Deer, drought, rabbit and aphid resistant – I’m so glad I planted this one in my planters this year as aphids have been a real problem for my Gaura. Thank goodness I didn’t rely on Gaura alone.
 
💜 Verbena stricta: Hoary Vervain is a wonderful clump forming perennial native North American plant with showy, long blooming spikes in summer. It is supremely drought tolerant & glides through drought with ease - few plants can say that! It self-seeds easily and looks great planted en masse. Hardy in planting zones 4-7 & needs full sun to thrive.
 
💜 Verbena hastata: Blue Vervain sport plenty of small but unique flowers & though technically it prefers moist areas like stream banks,  I see it growing in wild meadows just as often. It grows shorter with less moisture & that’s often a good trait. In a rain garden situation where I have it growing currently, I expect it to grow 6’! Native to much on North America, Verbena hastata is hardy in planting zones 4-8 , give it full sun and its very easy to grow from seed.
 
Vervain has also been used medically for centuries with 250 species worldwide! Also said to repel vampires – worth planting at least a few 🧛‍♀️💜🧛‍♀️💜

Lavender + Lavender alternatives for those that can’t grow lavender!
 
Lavendula might be the most popular flowering herb worldwide, but many have a hard time growing it. Even if you plant the hardiest varieties ( like this English Lavender shown) & give it exactly what it needs (full sun & well draining soil) its just one of those plants that on occasion you may lose a few. For those that find Lavender too fussy – here are some tough & reliable Lavender alternatives! 💜
 
Stachys ‘Hummello’ – A wonderful summer blooming & underused perennial that looks something like French Lavender. This tidy plant is great for the front of the border , flowers in a pinky/purple and doesn’t get too tall. 
 
Salvia ‘May Night’/Salvia sylvestris – Another purple flowering perennial that stays under 2’ , but this time with dark, indigo purple spike blossoms. As the name suggests it starts blooming in May, but with proper &  regular deadheading it might bloom on and off the whole garden season!
 
Catmint / Nepeta – I’ve had a love affair with Nepeta for many years. Another tidy & long blooming plant with many varieties available. I love ‘Walkers low’ for the middle or front of the border depending and Cats Pajamas for a low front of the garden accent. But my favourite is the white flowering variety ‘White Cloud’ (not shown).
 
Anise Hyssop / Agastache Foeniculum produces elongated dusky blue-purple blooms, &  its foliage has a licorice scent! Both the leaves and flowers are edible too. Blooms summer – fall. This native Canadian and USA plant is perfect for a pollinator habitat garden though it does get tall so give it room to grow. 
 
Russian Sage – Formerly Perovskia atriplicifolia now Salvia yangii – sports long spikes of lilac-coloured flowers and silvery foliage just like lavender does! Blooms in summer -fall. Though it can grow quite tall (up to 5’) there are shorter varieties - look for ‘Blue Jean Baby & Denim ‘n Lace’.
 
Save this Lavender alternatives list if you’ve had no luck growing Lavender💜

Many people mistake Goldenrod for Ragweed but its not even close to the same species. 
 
Ragweed is the one causes many people to have seasonal allergies(AKA Hay-fever)  NOT our native Goldenrod.
 
Goldenrod/ Solidago and all of it many species native to North America is so important to pollinators/birds/others that it has been touted as the single most important native North America plant for pollinator biodiversity! So many insects and wildlife depend on Goldenrod – it is in fact a Keystone species 🔑 
 
There is a Goldenrod / Solidago for any garden, and you don’t have to pick a tall one like you see typically growing on roadsides and meadows. Some aren’t even yellow! My favourites include:
 
 🤍 Upland White Goldenrod / Solidago ptarmicoides – Yep, a white Goldenrod grows about 2-3’ blooms August - September.
 
💛 Zigzag Goldenrod / Solidago flexicaulis – Grows 3’ tall blooms in August /September with yellow blossom and loves shade /part shade.
 
💙💛 Bluestem Goldenrod / Solidago caesia – Also grows 3’ tall blooms in August /September with yellow blossom and loves shade /part shade but this time with gracefully arching blue stems.
 
Don’t forget to include Goldenrod in your garden 🐝

Small backyard but want privacy? Find out how ⬇️ 
 
I know it hard to believe, but even in a small subdivision backyard can achieve near complete privacy over time with strategically placed privacy screens, poolside structures and small trees.
 
Of course, the larger the trees installed (like these Cedars) the faster privacy will happen. But in small planting areas like this, often its better to install a small tree so that it has the chance to grow in healthier instead of cramming in a large tree that has no room to grow.
 
Irrigation is another important thing to consider for planting beds such as these as which such little space they will likely dry out fast and need supplemental water. But – I’ve also seen irrigation systems give far too much water effectively killing the trees and plant life. 

Overwatering is the quickest way to kill a tree and the soil needs to dry out between watering for the health of the plant.  Hint: Irrigation for gardens should never be everyday - usually 2-3 times per week is plenty!
 
The only way to really know about the moisture in your gardens is to stick your finger in the soil and if you feel moisture don’t water. If its dry its time to water! Or purchase an inexpensive moisture meter for an accurate reading.
 
Landscape Design and inhouse rendering by Melanie Rekola @ladylandscape

Crushing on CATMINT!
 
Calamintha Nepeta spp. sometimes called Lesser Catmint is one of my go-to , hardy, front of the border perennials. It stays short (12” – 24”) and blooms profusely starting in summer and continues into fall!
 
I love its frothy white flowers as do the bees & butterflies – there are always a cloud of happy insects surrounding it! Yet deer and rabbits generally leave its fragrant foliage alone. Most species of Calamintha are hardy zone 5- 7 and even up to zone 9 but its always good to check as new varieties are being produced often.
 
PRO TIP: Shear Calamintha back after the first flush of flowers have faded to encourage more flowering 🌸
 
Calamintha nepeta is native to Europe and the Mediterranean region but its not an invasive species in other areas of the world. Even though it is from the mint family, it is clump forming and doesn’t run out of control like many mints do. It’s reliable, low maintenance, and drought tolerant once established. 
 
Do you grow Catmint? Which are your favourites?

What plants are best for supporting pollinators? Plants native to your area!
 
There is no one size fits all – each area is unique. Plants & pollinators evolved together to support each other, & without each other they cannot survive.
 
The term pollinator includes more species than you may think. Bees, butterflies, birds, bats, beetles, flies, wasps, & moths are all important pollinators. 
 
Many pollinating insects require a specific host plant for their larva to feed on – no other plant can take its place. Just like Milkweed is the only plant edible to Monarch caterpillars, there are many other creatures that have evolved this way too.
 
Of course, a constant food source is also very important for pollination support.  Native plants provide a better food source than non-natives and often provide more nectar and nutritious seeds in winter too.
 
A pollinator friendly gardens should include all types of native species, including native trees and shrubs. Trees & shrubs are also host plants & often provide the most nutrition. Plus, they provide shelter & nesting opportunities! 
 
Shown here is this gorgeous, pink mid- late summer blooming Obedient Plant / Physostegia virginiana and it blooms into fall too.  Plant it carefully as its not exactly obedient in some garden situations where it can spread aggressively, but its perfect for large and naturalized spaces. Its native North American range is from Eastern Canada through to northern Mexico.
 
Please include natives in your garden – try for 70% and the other 30% can be all your other favourites so long as they aren’t invasive! Always check with your state or province when including a new plant just in case 🙏

Don’t forget the climbers 🌱 
 
Vines add so much to garden such as lushly textured greenery, flowers, and berries, offing a long season of interest.  The birds, bees and local wildlife will appreciate them too as they offer food, nesting sites and habitat.
 
Vines are a great fix-all for many garden situations! They add height & privacy and fit into narrow spaces where trees cannot. Climbers can also hide many garden uglys such as screening a neighbour’s trash pile or to hiding salmon-pink brick like I show here
 
Shown here:
 
🌱 Dutchman’s Pipe/ Aristolochia macrophylla – Large heart-shaped leaves cover this great foliage vine. Fast growing & needs a sturdy support. North American native with a range from southeastern Canada to eastern USA.

🌱 American Bittersweet / Celastrus scandens – Pretty, mid-sized leaves, flowers white in springtime followed by orange berries that persist most of the winter. They feed migratory birds that return in early spring when not much food is available. North American native with a range from central to eastern.

🌱 Trumpet Vine / Campsis Radicans - Fast growing & needs a sturdy support plus can spread/sucker so do plant carefully! I think its worth planting in the correct situation as it blooms for months in summer. Hummingbirds flock to it! Native to eastern North America & naturalized elsewhere in NA.

🌱 Boston Ivy / Parthenocissus tricuspidata – This Ivy will not damage brick & will actually protect it - so long as the brickwork is intact to begin with. When grown on a house like this is cuts down on air conditioning costs too. Yes, it needs to be cut out of the gutters yearly but still a great quick fix for the pink brick, I think! Native to China & Japan but not invasive like English Ivy is here.
 
 Don’t forget to save this list for later!

For anyone wondering if 3D renderings are necessary for a landscape project - this post is for you!
 
Swipe through to see all the unique features - the luxury veggie garden entrance, the floating bbq, the outdoor movie space with rill water feature & the bespoke shade structure concepts. The 2D plan is at the end for comparison 👀 
 
If you’ve never worked with a landscape designer before, you may not realize – you can’t build from 3D renderings alone. The 2D plan is the most important part of the design as it shows actual distances , sq footages , pedestrian flow and plant labels. 

3D renderings are just concepts – but as you can see they do help make sense of the 2D plan for many. Plantings are hard to show properly in 3D too because plants are living things and don’t always grow in exactly the way you envision.
 
So – do you need 3D renderings? I don’t think they are completely necessary as when inspirational photos area added to 2D plans they can help a lot to help envision a space. But if you have a hard time reading plan view or planning on building a large landscape project with unique features - I think its worth the extra cost. Only about 20% of my client’s request 3D renderings. Most of my work is done in regular ol’ plan view.
 
I began this design for the project shown 3 years ago – luxury veggie gardens gained great popularity in the beginning of Covid times, and I was happy to accommodate! It’s been a longtime build process, but I’m happy to report it should be complete this fall/next springtime. 

I can’t wait to show you!

Hydrangeas not blooming? Plant these no fail types!
 
I’m a firm believer in planting the correct plant in the correct environment. Here in the North (planting zone 5) the most reliable Hydrangeas are Hydrangea paniculata and Hydrangea arborescence. Don’t even bother planting Macrophylla! If you do all you’ll get is tons of leaves but hardly any flowers unless it’s a particularly wet year like this one. If your hydrangeas aren’t or barely blooming, you probably have Macrophylla. I wish nurseries wouldn’t entice people to waste their money with these in my area. Just because they have beautiful blooms in the nursery doesn’t mean they bloom beautifully in your garden!
 
Other reasons you’re having Hydrangea troubles?
 
• Not enough sun - 6 hours or more is best.

• You’re pruning too late in the spring. Hydrangeas like paniculata and arborescence should be pruned in late winter/ early spring before the new growth emerges. Otherwise, you’ll get subpar blossoms.

• You pruned to the ground. Never prune Hydrangea  paniculata more than 1 third of the whole plant. Arborescence should be pruned to 6” or higher to ensure strong stems. Always remove spindly growth from either type leaving only the strong stems in place.

• You fertilized. Hydrangeas should be planted in good quality garden soil , ideally with some bonemeal and Mycorrhizal inoculant. After that you shouldn’t have to ever fertilize them again. Many fertilizers will ensure your plant grows lots of green leaves with hardly any flowers! Its better to skip the chemical fertilizers all together.
 
Shown here:
 
Hydrangea paniculata ‘ Limelight’
Hydrangea paniculata ‘Zinfin Doll’
Hydrangea arborescence ‘ Annabelle’
Hydrnagea paniculata Rehny’ (Vanilla Strawberry’)
Hydrangea arborescence ‘Abetwo’ (Incrediball)

Save this hardy hydrangea list! 🌸

Why plant sunflowers every year when you can plant these perennial ones once? 🌻
 
Perennial Sunflower (AKA Sunchokes / Helianthus Tuberosus) is a gorgeous, easy, and edible plant. 

It grows tall (like most Sunflowers) up to 10’ with many classic sunflower yellow blossoms. Though each bloom is smaller than typical Sunflowers, they make up for that in abundance! 

Perennial Sunflowers are excellent host plants for73 different butterflies (and other insects too) plus provide habitat and important late-season food source for many pollinators. They make great cut flowers too!
 
Known as ‘skibwan’ by the Anishinaabe, give Sunchokes room as they can spread aggressively in the garden, but if you dig and eat at least half the tubers after first frost you’d keep it in check and have many tasty and nutritious meals too! Slice raw Sunchokes thinly and add to salads, add to soups/stews or roast with other root veggies.
 
Plant it in full sun to part shade – its not fussy about soil either. Native to Eastern North America 🇨🇦 🇺🇸

White themed gardens are timeless & forever fashionable!
 
I’m a huge fan of white in the garden and I love mixing it with other light, pastel hued flowers to give it a “nearly white” look that sparkles and glows in the evening. The evening is when most of us spend time in our gardens anyway so why not make them look their very best at twilight?
 
White mixes well with almost every other colour, but for a purist all-white garden you must be careful when mixing white flowers: Some white hues can look dirty when placed alongside other pure white tones.
 
Another benefit of white flowers is , they attract the night shift of pollinators such as moths and beetles. Moths are said to more efficient that daytime pollinators but face unique hardships such a light pollution. Light pollution impairs their ability to find mates, evade predators and locate/pollinate food sources. 

Don’t forget to turn off/put your outdoor lights on a timer. Lucky with the illuminating & reflective qualities of white outdoors in flowers, furniture and textiles you may not need much supplemental light 💡

Your Panicle Hydrangeas won’t stay white forever so you may as well like their colour change!
 
There are so many beautiful Panicle Hydrangea varieties , and this Hydrangea paniculate ‘Rehny’ is one of my favourites.  It opens pure white, then progresses to unique bicoloured pink and white blossoms, finally progressing to a spectacular strawberry shade! If you prune it at the correct time (late winter to early spring) you’d get these HUGE flower heads.
 
I love it for its long season of interest! You can also dry these hydrangea flowers at any point in the season and they will retain their colour at harvest too. Just put them in vase and fill with water to only about ¼ the total vase volume. They’ll drink up the water then dry perfectly. 
 
Panicle Hydrangeas aren’t fussy and bloom reliably even in northern climates to zone 3 / 4. They bloom later than other hydrangea types.
 
I prefer Hydrangea paniculatas that look good for months, even as the weather turns colder like this Vanilla Strawberry Hydrangea shown - but there are others that also have a long season of interest like  Zinfin Doll and Little Lime Punch.
 
I know a lot of you grumble about deer eating your hydrangeas, but I must mention that if deer are starving from habitat loss (which many are in the USA) they will eat anything to survive. You could try planting a special garden with favourite deer edibles to help them, and so they leave your hydrangea alone ✌️

To you it’s a beautiful garden, but to nature it’s a lifeline❤️‍🩹 
 
You don’t have to choose between a beautiful garden & one that’s friendly to wildlife – they can be both. You also don’t have to completely redo your garden to make it wildlife-friendly either – just follow these simple  tips:
 
• Plant some straight native plants to your region. You don’t have to remove all your favourite flowers, just remove, & replace anything you don’t love each year. Native plants can be supremely beautiful! They are the key to providing the best nutrition & often the only food that certain insect babies can eat.

• Don’t plant invasive species as these displace natural ecosystems & create unnecessary pressure. Each location is different – always check before adding new plants & remove any existing invasives.

• Don’t cut your garden back in Fall! Seedheads provide food for wildlife, & the stocks/leaves provide overwintering habitat for many insects. Also leave your leaves – they’ll provide you with rich garden soil as they break down. Plus - butterflies are hibernating in there so don’t mulch those leaves ☠️ 

• Don’t cut your garden back in springtime until its above 10 degrees Celsius for 10 days consecutively. Hibernating bees, butterflies & more are hibernating & don’t wake up until its warm enough that lots of food-flowers are available.

• Don’t use chemicals in your garden 🛑 Pesticides don’t care which life form they are killing & rodent poison gets passed down the food web killing other animals like owls, fox and cats. There is no need to use chem fertilizer – those fertilizer companies are lying. Start with healthy garden soil & use natural fertilizers like bone meal & mycorrhizae inoculant. I haven’t used any chem fertilizer in 20 years! 

• Add a water source - this can be just a simple shallow bowl 💦 
 
Little lives matter - Please share if you agree ✨
