Is Modern Farmhouse over 🤔

Modern Farmhouse style has been around for more than 10 years already, making it look tired to some. But if you have a century Farmstead like this, how could you not beautify it inside and outside, in classic Farmhouse style?
 
What makes this outdoor space design classic regardless of trends are the clean lines of the walkways and retaining walls in a light, large format natural stone, installed in a timeless, random pattern.
 
Stone patterns in patios and walkways don’t get nearly enough attention. I think the key to making patterns outdoor work is – the patio pattern size must be significantly larger than the pattern on the exterior of the home. Ideally it should also be a contrasting pattern! Large format with less seams always looks more expensive – therefore luxury.
 
Ornamental grasses sway and suit the characteristic period Homestead so well, reminiscent of seasonal wheat crop in my opinion.
 
Evergreen boxwood hedging lines the walkways providing structure and winter interest. The gardens and landscape design around the rest of the property is more vibrant and diverse but for a nice, low maintenance front entrance that always looks good – this is a great combo!
 
Would love your impute -  Is Modern Farmhouse here to stay, or are you so over it? There are no wrong answers 👇

Outdoor design tips for small spaces ✨

Small spaces can be just as impactful as large ones with a strategic design plan. Follow these simple guidelines to make the most of your small backyard!

 *  Don’t cut out the garden spaces. Gardens are often the first thing that gets sacrificed in small space design, but I think this is the biggest mistake. Just because there is more space for outdoor living, ask yourself: will you actually want to spend time out there without plant life? Backyards without plants are both hot AND cold. Hot because there aren’t any plants to absorb heat/give shade and cold because there isn’t anything living or beauty to admire.

 *  Hide the fence! When you can easily see a fence on all sides it makes you backyard feel smaller, almost like a playpen. Hide it by layering hedging, small trees, and privacy screens. This blurs the edges of your property making it appear larger.

 *  Privacy is the new luxury and you should use sheds and outdoor structures to your advantage.  Is your neighbours outdoor living space adjacent to yours? Use sheds and structures to a provide a sound and sight barrier.  Also - don’t purchase that 10’ x 10’ gazebo unless you’re using is for only a small dining table or a few chairs. There is not proper space for anything else – I don’t know why this is a commonly sold size.

 *  Don’t pick everything small scale. If all you choose is size small for furniture, planters, and plants you’ll achieve a mouse house feel making your yard appear smaller. Adding an oversized focal point or two does so much to elevate and extend the feeling of a garden room.

3 years later – not one tulip left 🌷 
 
Seeing all the beautiful tulip photos from The Netherlands, its easy to understand why so many of us plant them. They are certainly beautiful – but the DO NOT last! Squirrels love to eat them & they aren’t true perennials. They may come back for a few years with less and less flowers eventually petering down to none. 

Not worth it in my opinion when you can plant daffodils / narcissus and get more & more flowers each year!
 
Daffodils don’t have to be large/ bright yellow either. There are other colours available such as white, pink a& orange in many combinations. Personally, I find the types labeled as pink, in reality are more orangey & I find they don’t naturalize as well as the other colours. I love the white varieties best 🤍
 
Smaller Daffs don’t get used nearly enough. I find a combination of small, medium, and large flowers make the biggest & best impact ✨
 
Different daffodil varieties bloom at different times and for different lengths. Plant long blooming varieties & ones that bloom in early, mid and late spring.
 
Here are my favs:
 
Mount Hood – large + long blooming from early to mid spring.  Opens soft yellow maturing to pure white

Thalia – a petite white variety blooming mid to late spring

Tete-a-Tete – small, mid spring + long flowering in sunny yellow

Golden Echo – small & very long blooming early to late spring! Combination of white + yellow
 
Save the list for 3 months of garden beauty!
 
For clarity: Species tulips (tulips that aren’t hybridized) are the only ones that are true perennials. Though years ago, I had one soggy spring and lost all of those too! And though Daffs are generally squirrel proof, if you plant your bulbs with bonemeal the squirrels can be attracted to that. And if they’re starving, they may try to eat the daffodils anyway even though they’re toxic 💀

Don’t cut back your Hydrangea paniculata for winter!
 
If you do, you’ll miss out of months of much needed interest in wintertime. Plus, leaving the flowers intact gives the plant a little extra protection during the cold months.
 
I know many people are concerned of their Hydrangea breaking off in the snow, and in certain conditions (like very wet snow) yes – some branches may break.  But if they do it isn’t a problem because Hydrangea paniculate bloom on new wood (meaning the branches that grow the following spring) . Most snowfall if fairly lightweight so you’ll get to enjoy pretty snow on your dried-on-the-branch hydrangea flowers throughout the winter. But never shovel or blow snow onto them as that kind of snow is very compacted and heavy.
 
Prune Panicle Hydrangea like these Limelights in late winter or early spring before the new leaves start to emerge. This way you’ll get strong branches with the largest flower heads!

An unpopular opinion, which is why I had to prove it!
 
The Leave the Leaves experiment: 

To be clear: Leaf piles absolutely smother lawn, but so often fallen leaves (depending on the amount) don’t. Even with all the trees here, this number of leaves stayed all winter, then gradually decomposed completely into the lawn all on there own by July the following year. The lawn was healthier for it! 

Save time & effort! Leave you leaves because they’re a wonderful natural fertilizer for your lawn and garden soil. I have left most of the leaves in my gardens for the past 15 years too with great results.
 
I did not mulch the leaves because many insects & other wildlife are overwintering in the leaves. Butterfly & moth chrysalises look a lot like dead leaves too! Do not mulch leaves if you care for nature 🙏
 
If you have many large trees (more than shown here) , you could have too many leaves that would smother a lawn or garden, and in that case – its best to pile them into an area were they can be left (like under shrubs and trees) . Avoid bagging them if you can – don’t throw away next years fire flies & pollinators ✨🐝🦋
 
I’ll be replacing most of this lawn soon and winter sowing it with native plant seeds.  Follow and stick around to see how it turns out! 💚

My one true love - Gaura ‘Whirling Butterflies’ 🌸
 
Gaura ‘Whirling Butterflies’– formerly know as Gaura lindheimeri now classified as Oenothera lindheimeri has been my #1 plant crush for a long time, but I’ve hardly been talking about her here. 

The perfect flowering plant with long, airy stems that dance gracefully in the wind. It blooms from June – frost with tiny butterfly-like blossoms in abundance! Bees (especially the Bumbles) love them 🐝 
 
I grow Gaura in a planter here in zone 5 and because even though it’s labelled as hardy 5-9 planting zones, it doesn’t overwinter for me in the garden. That said I do know others in zone 5 who have overwintered their Gaura for years successfully! I’ve also overwintered mine in my unheated garage. Just place in the garage after freeze up and water sparingly throughout the winter. In early April bring you planter out & water as needed. 
 
Truth be told my Gaura planters didn’t fair as well this year. We had lots of rain & little sun - plus I had an aphid invasion! I’ve never had aphid problem before, but aphids are a known pest of Gaura. 
 
So what can be done for aphid infestations?

If it isn’t very many, spraying them off with hose or hand picking them can work

Another option is applying a solution of 1 gallon water + 4 tbs (non antibacterial or with fragrance) dish or castile soap , via spray bottle. Spray the infected plant, leave for a few hours then rinse off the plant. Reapply as needed.

Dusting the entire plants with Diatomaceous earth is another great option, but if you do you must cover it or move it inside for few days, so you don’t unintentionally end up killing beneficial insects that visit the flowers. Diatomaceous earth is an all-natural substance that is very small & sharp effectively killing any insect by lacerating their skin which dries them out. But after it gets wet its ineffective. It also works great in the house to control ants & fleas! 
 
How did your Gaura fair this 2023 season?

Lazy gardening that benefits everyone ✨
 
I never understood why people cut back their gardens in fall. From an esthetic standpoint, its much more beautiful to see dried seed heads & leaves sprinkled with snow in winter, rather than just a flat snow-blanket of nothing.
 
Leaving your gardens standing and not raking out leaves benefits the native bees hibernating in the dead flower stocks, the butterflies, fireflies and other insects overwintering in the leaves, feeds/provides protection for birds/wildlife and helps soil microbes too. I haven’t done a fall cleanup in my own garden for more that 20 years.
 
Leaving your garden standing also helps your garden retain more snow/moisture and the snow acts as extra insulation which protects your plants.
 
When should you cut back your gardens? In springtime after its 10 degrees Celsius for 10 days. This is a good rule of thumb because the soil needs to warm up enough so that hibernating pollinators wake up at a time when there’s enough food sources available for them to survive. Don’t unknowingly throw away your pollinators!
 
I know fall clean up was a standard gardening practice for many years, but this is outdated thinking, and we know better now. 

The more you know the more you grow - please share if you agree 🙏

Annual, biennial, perennial, bulb/ephemeral – what’s the difference?
 
With so many different plants available for our gardens, the terms can be confusing! Here’s what you need to know:
 
Annual: Annual plants only live for one garden season & their soul purpose is to pump out as many flowers as they can to produce seeds. It’s important to remove spent blossoms (know as deadheading) for many annual plants like these Cosmos, so the plant keeps producing flowers. Once they start setting seed they don’t need to flower anymore. Deadheading works for many perennial plants too.
 
Biennial: Probably the most confusing, biennial plants like these Foxglove/ Digitalis purpurea produce leaves the first year & flowers in their second year. The second-year flowers produce seeds which then sow themselves in the garden creating an ongoing cycle. This is why, if you want biennial plants to flower in your garden every year, you must plant them two years in row. Perhaps this sounds fussy to have to plant more than once and this is likely why biennial plants are disappearing from garden design altogether. Such a loss, I think! So easy to grow from seed, just spread them two years in a row in prepared beds. I have the best success sowing them in late fall/early winter. 
 
Perennial: The easiest plant to understand, these herbaceous types come back every year for at least two & some up to 100 yrs+) Peonies are one that can grow very old in the correct conditions. Some spread by sending out new roots or shoots & some via their seeds too. Perennial shown – everyone’s favourite North American native - Purple Coneflower – Echinacea purpurea.
 
Ephemeral/bulb/corm: Another confusing plant, ephemerals are typically perennials – but most only bloom for a period (usually spring) then retreats below the surface, hidden until the following year. Most are only available in Fall & planted between existing garden plants, so you don’t unknowingly dig them up! Daffodil, Allium (Purple Sensation shown) & Trillium are all ephemeral plants. 
 
I hope you learned something 🌱

Focus on A N E M O N E 🌸
 
Anemones are a fan favourite for gardeners with their poppy like flowers that sway in the slightest breeze, hence their common name “Windflower”. They’ve been a plant crush of mine for 20 years already!
 
Many types have lovely foliage , even the unopened flower buds add interest, and they bloom anytime between spring and fall depending on the variety. There is an Anemone for any garden!
 
Here are my long-time favs below.
 
🌸 Images 1-3 - Anemone x hybrida ‘Honorine Jobert’ – My number 1 favourite of the Japanese Anemones with beautiful white blossoms held atop wiry stems. However, the term Japanese doesn’t really fit as they’re actually from China! I find they do they best planted in part sun, and bloom in abundance from mid summer – early fall. Hardy zones 4-8
 
🌸 Images 4-6 Anemone x hybrida ‘Montrose’ – My second favourite Japanese Anemone. Very similar to the above mentioned but with slightly shaggy petals in a soft pink colour that is so welcome late in the garden season.
 
🌸 Image 7 - Anemone canadensis – A native Canadian Anemone with a range into the USA too. Usually used as a ground cover for its attractive foliage, but also has beautiful blossoms in May through June. It does it best in full sun to partial shade. This anemone can spread quickly and overwhelm less vigorous plants thus works best planted with other perennials of equal vigor.
 
🌸 Image 8 - Anemone Blanda – A low growing and spring blooming Anemone that hails from Europe,  usually sold as corms in Fall. Plant is large clusters along walkways and allow to naturalize under deciduous shrubs and tree for big spring impact. The whole plant dies back after flowing so they’re best planted with perennials that will fill that gap as they garden season progresses.

Berries – what your garden is missing 🔴🔴🔴
 
Gardens should have interest in all four seasons and plants that produce berries are well worth investing in. 

Most berry-producers are woody plants that provide structure and framework to a garden, they flower AND produce berries. Cumulatively this is a lot of interest coming from just one plant! And more that just for esthetic purposes, said flowers and berries also provide food for bees, birds and other wildlife. They’re truly win/win/win additions to any garden.
 
Shown – all North American native plants except for #1 and all have berries that typically persist throughout wintertime:
 
🔴 Crabapple / Malus unknown variety
 
🔴 Staghorn Sumac / Rhus typhina (Native)
 
🟠 American Bittersweet / Celastrus scandens (Native)
 
🔴 American Highbush Cranberry / Viburnum trilobum (Native)
 
🔴 American Mountain Ash / Sorbus americana (Native)
 
A wonderful thing about berries that are present throughout winter is - they are often the first foods available for migratory, fruit eating birds in early spring like robins and orioles whose diets don’t usually include seeds.

And finally, when you include berries in your outdoor space you can skip a lot of Christmas decorating! They look festive for the season all on their own.

The secret to creating a low maintenance garden? Plant it densely🙌
 
All gardens take some maintenance, but I’ve learned from experience that when plants are spread far apart with a lot of soil showing - the soil dries out faster and weeds quickly infiltrate. Different plants have different types of root systems allowing them to live together harmoniously. 

Swipe to image 3 for an infographic on what’s going on beneath the soil in a meadow or perennial garden. 

Some perennials can be very long lived (even 100 yrs) and have tap roots that reach 8’ deep!
 
When a garden is planted intensively, the root matrix doesn’t easily allow weeds to penetrate and take root.  Amazingly, through the mycorrhizal network that surrounds and connects these roots over time, the plants actually share resources and are healthier. Yet another reason I never suggest cultivating the top layer of soil in garden, as cultivating breaks surface roots and the mycorrhizae web.
 
Of course there is never a one size fits all for gardening, and plants susceptible to moulds may resent not having airspace – but this is why choosing the correct plant for the correct conditions is crucial. By choosing plants that enjoy the same conditions you’ll save yourself a lot of time and effort ✨
 
In a general sense, gardens with biodiversity are healthier than those with only a few species of plants. It’s the very rigid planting plans that are susceptible to the largest maintenance, weed & pest problems. Very likely due to the lack of root matrix beneath the soil!
 
Hope you learned something today ☀️

Bittersweet Vine / Celastrus scandens 🆚 Celastrus orbiculatus
 
Bittersweet is a beautiful vine to include in your garden but are you planting the correct one? Photos 1,3,5 are our native North American Bittersweet Celastrus scandens & photos 2,4,6 are Asian Bittersweet / Celastrus orbiculatus
 
I learned the hard way about this lovely plant. I purchased it from a nursey many years ago and what I thought I was purchasing was our native North American Bittersweet / Celastrus scandens but what I got instead was Oriental Bittersweet / Celastrus orbiculatus. It took me years to figure out I received the wrong plant!
 
🟠🔴 Oriental Bittersweet is a highly invasive species here in North America which can easily grow 100’ & quickly choke out our important native species with its dense foliage & strangling stems/trunks. Yes – it is beautiful, but it should not be planted here. Both types of Bittersweet have orange berries when they are closed, but Oriental Bittersweets berries open red. It has berries that run along the whole branch and Its leaves are rounder. 
 
🟠🟠 American Bittersweet / Celastrus scandens is far more well behaved that the invasive Asian Bittersweet. It does need a sturdy support and room to grow but only up to 25’. Its berries start out orange and they’re interior is also orange. The berries are larger that the Asian variety and held in clusters toward the end of branch rather than along it. Its leaves are have pointy ends too.
 
I think Bittersweet has a bad reputation because of the confusion between varieties! And what’s worse is that both types can crossbreed too. If you plan on planting the “good” one for Canada &  the USA you must plant both a male and a female plant if you want the berries - and of course you want them 🟠🟠🟠

The biggest problem I see in ineffective landscape designs? Issues with scale ⚖️
 
For example, the fountain looks large in the first pic, but if you swipe you can see its in perfect scale with the rest of the garden courtyard. This fountain is actually a 2.5 radius – meaning is 5’ across! And although this size may sound scary, its what was needed here. This also applies to planters – size up if you’re ever in doubt.
 
Other scale problem I see is skinny pathways. Paths should be a minimum of 4’ wide and wider still if the run is long. I know a lot of you in the field of interior design may question this necessary width, but the difference between interior design and exterior design is (again) scale. Outside the home is a much larger space than the interior in most cases!
 
And the final scale problem I see regularly is garden beds that are far too slim. I feel garden beds should be at least 4’ wide to get any kind of good composition & gardens against a home should be at least 1/3 the height of the home. 

Some may ask, but what if I’m planting just a row of cedars? Can my soil space be thinner then? You could but I wouldn’t recommend it.  Cramming trees into tight spaces and expecting them to thrive is never a good, long-term plan. Our gardens are legacies that may be enjoyed by future generations so we must give them what they need for a healthy, long-term life 💚

 
Landscape Design by Melanie Rekola @ladylandscape

Yes – Gaura ‘Whirling Butterflies” dances 💃 
 
Static, shrub-based gardens just aren’t the same - nothing catches your eye like movement does! Gaura lovers know this well
 
🌸 Also known as Bee blossom & Wandflower, Oenothera lindheimeri has all the right attributes to catch the wind. Delicate flowers come in abundance from June – frost and dance atop slender stems. Bumble bees flock to these beautiful blossoms!
 
🌸 Gaura “Whirling Butterflies’ is drought tolerant perennial native to Texas and Louisiana and is labelled a hardy zones 5-9 but I find its more like a zone 6. It can have invasive tendencies as some have mentioned , but I personally haven’t had any problems. Its doesn’t overwinter in this planter shown, but I have had success overwintering it in my unheated garage.
 
Earlier this year I had a Reel about this plant go viral and I know many of you found me because of this plant! 

If you love Gaura like I do let me know below - I’d love to connect 🌸 Gaura Lovers Unite! 🌸

Planning for a new swimming pool in 2024? Here’s what you need to know ⬇️ 

💦 What shape to choose? Everyone has their own opinion, of course but for me rectangular is the best choice because it’s elegant. A rectangular pool is both modern & classic and will never go out of style. Installing a swimming pool is a significant investment, so choose a style that you’ll love for a long time. 

💦 Should you have a deep end? Though smaller plunge pools are more popular currently, many people with kids want to pool with a deep end. Just know you’ll need a longer pool to accommodate this - usually at least 30’ and longer still, if you want it to be safe for diving. Also, consider the monthly heating chemical and pumping cost of all that extra water. 

💦 even if a property is large, I still suggest placing a swimming pool close to the house. It will get more use due to its close proximity plus you’ll also receive the beautiful reflective qualities of the pool water. Swimming pools are like giant mirrors, reflecting your home and its surroundings. 

💦 I also suggest considering outdoor furniture placements early on in the pool design process. I can’t tell you how many times I’ve walked into a new clients backyard & see a lovely pool and patio but there’s no space for lounges or a dining table. You need to have room for the furniture as well as functional traffic flow around it. The open spaces are just as important as the used spaces. 

💦 what pool interior colour to choose? If you’ve been following here for a while, you likely already know - I think grey is the nicest pool interior colour available. It can be light or dark, depending on your preference - any shade of gray produces a soft blue water colour because it reflects the sky. But whatever you do, don’t choose blue if you want your swimming pool to look high-end 💰 

💦 and finally - keep some money aside from your Pool and Landscape budget for plantings and outdoor furniture. These final details make all the difference to the final effect!

A lot of landscape designers focus on adding “a pop of colour” to the outdoors but I think adding texture is even more important 
 
In photo 1 this outdoor dining space has a warm, elegant vibe due to combination of natural textures: the slatted wood wall & wood soffits, natural stone patio , & native evergreen Eastern White Cedar hedging behind. The deciduous (and native) Paper Birch tree is the perfect juxtaposition to the rougher texture of the Cedar and the see through glass railing allows a beautiful, seamless view of all – but as always: Glass railings should be installed with bird-safe markers to avoid bird strike fatalities. Let’s keep our birdlife safe!
 
Photo 2 shows a custom metal wood holder that adds an interesting patten & texture to the outdoor space. Though it can’t act as the pool fence given that its climbable, it does provide lots of privacy from the road and dampens street noise too.
 
The third photo highlights the lovely, natural stone façade of the home. Though this feature was obviously existing, I certainly didn’t want to hide or compete with it!
 
I think a pop of texture is much more beautiful and impactful than a pop of colour – agree or disagree?

Tiny house, big outdoor living 🙌
 
Not everyone needs to hire a landscape designer, but if you want to more than double your living space for half the year like these tiny homeowners did, having a thoughtful design in place is imperative.
 
It might surprise you to hear that I don’t immediately “see the design” when I first visit a site. There are many things to consider such as: how will the clients use their outdoor space, functional outdoor living areas with good traffic flow and accessibility, esthetics(of course) , sun and shade, wind, soil type, views to highlight and views in need of screening. There is a lot of though that goes into a landscape design!
 
Sometimes a design gets implemented exactly as its drawn but more often there are tweaks to the design made during construction. I’ve even done this myself at my own home! But even if there are changes, the design still works as a communication tool between the contractor and the homeowner.  However, changes should be made with caution as one change affects other aspects of the plan. Sometimes a domino effect happens, and the entire vison gets lost along the way.
 
In this landscape plan we included:
 
A dining + cooking deck
Sunken lounge space
A fire space with Moon gate arbours
An outdoor sauna
Hot and cold plunge spas
100% native gardens
Outdoor shower (not shown)
 
Could you live in a Tiny house if you had all the outdoor living space for 6 months of the year? I think I could!

A design problem I see far too often - Waterfalls that are far too loud 📣
 
I see why the idea of tall waterfalls are appealing, but unfortunately that’s the difference between the idea and reality. I can’t tell you how many times I’ve seen tall ones installed on a pool or pond and they’re so loud that the homeowners don’t even use them. 

Loud waterfalls are definitely not Zen and what’s the point of having them if you can’t even have a conversation over them?
 
These backyard waterfalls are only 15” between the top of the waterfall to the pond water height. This short fall offers plenty of sound to drown out neighbourhood lawn mowers and street noise but is subtle enough for intimate conversation.
 
The only time I think taller waterfalls are appropriate: if they are very slim (like slender spout scuppers or 6” wide or less sheer decent). These don’t create so much sound as there’s less water hitting the surface. Another type that can work is a sheer rain type of waterfall. As their name suggests, these offer a slow water projection,  much like rainfall! But I’ve also seen this type installed incorrectly with too much waterflow making them (again) too loud.
 
Sound matters! Keep them short if you’re in doubt 💦 
 
Landscape Design by Melanie Rekola @ladylandscape
